ik you probably wont be needing it now but ill explain it anyway , first you need to find the heat energy required to raise the temp of the water from 15 to 100 celcius . which is 1*4.2*(100-15) = 357 and to change 100 C water to 100C steam you need to apply latent heat capacity since phase change occurs ( latent specific heat capacity(l) = 2260 kj)( q=m*l for phase change )  q = 1*2260 = 2260 and to change 100C steam to 115 C  steam ( specific heat of steam = 2.1 Kj ) so q= 1 * 2.1*(115-100) = 31.5 and the total heat energy required to change 15 to 115 is = 357 + 2260 + 31.5 = 2548 KJ and i did all these stepss using J unit , you can also use cal unit ( 1 cal = 4.2 KJ)

Around 23:00. The question having Aluminum,Iron and Water... There's a mistake behind his approach. The Element with the highest temp will lose heat to the others with low temp. Simply put... Aluminum at 120°c will lose heat to Iron metal at 90°c and water at 15°c cos the Conservation law of heat says that heat will flow from the higher region to the lower.  Asides that.... 22.50: I need to rewrite the equation for you. 90(T-120) + 67.5(T-90) = -80(4.184)(T-15). See the difference: 67.5(T-90) instead of 67.5(T-120) as in the video, therefore the final answer should be T = 44.48 degrees Celcius. T refers to the final temperate here.

One of the substances loses heat energy, and the other gains it. Thus one side is negative. I'm not sure why he has the metal as positive though, since the metal is hot and loses heat to the water. I felt like the metal should be negative for that reason.
The other side is always the opposite of the other because heat is lost and gained. That was why he said "it does not really matter where you put the negative sign as long as its in the equation".
The side which gains heat needs a negative sign.
